title.value: Sum and Tensor of Quantitative Effects
title.justification: The title accurately reflects the primary concepts discussed throughout the paper, which are the sum and tensor operations on quantitative effects in the context of algebraic theories and monads.
title.quote: SUM AND TENSOR OF QUANTITATIVE EFFECTS

extractions.description: The paper explores the theory of combining quantitative algebraic effects using sum and tensor operations. It extends classical algebraic operations to quantitative frameworks, introducing concepts like quantitative equational theories. The work provides categorical correspondences for these combinations when applied to effects modeled by monads, offering an algebraic perspective on several coalgebraic structures including Markov processes and Mealy machines with bisimilarity metrics. The paper builds upon prior work in algebraic effects and computational semantics.

type.justification: The study is primarily focused on developing theories and categorical frameworks for quantitative equational theories, sum and tensor of effects, and algebraic presentations. The paper's work on algebraic frameworks and mathematical proofs without empirical experiments highlights this theoretical nature.
type.quote: As our main result, we show that the sum and tensor of two quantitative equational theories correspond to the categorical sum (i.e., coproduct) and tensor, respectively, of their effects qua monads.

name.justification: The paper primarily deals with the algebraic structures and category-theoretic concepts in the context of quantitative equational theories.
name.quote: Quantitative algebraic effects are monadic computational effects on categories of metric spaces, which, moreover, have an algebraic presentation in the form of quantitative equational theories.

name.justification: The focus is on extending traditional algebraic theories to handle quantitative aspects, indicative of a significant overlap with quantitative frameworks in mathematics and computer science.
name.quote: Providing quantitative analogues of the following monad transformers due to Moggi: exception, resumption, reader, and writer transformers.

name.justification: The paper applies the theories to concrete computational structures like Markov processes and Mealy machines, emphasizing its contribution to the study of coalgebraic structures.
name.quote: We provide the first quantitative algebraic axiomatizations to the following coalgebraic structures: Markov processes, labelled Markov processes, Mealy machines, and Markov decision processes.
